content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the functions given by <math alttext="f of x equals, e to the x power, minus 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </msup> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="g of x equals, negative 3 times x squared, plus 7" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <mn>7</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the shaded region bounded by the graphs of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, and the vertical line <math alttext=" x equals 1" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, as shown in Figure 1. Let <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi></math> be the shaded region in Quadrant IV bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis, and the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-axis, as shown in Figure 2.

(a) Find the area of <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>R</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the functions given by <math alttext="f of x equals, e to the x power, minus 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </msup> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="g of x equals, negative 3 times x squared, plus 7" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <mn>7</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the shaded region bounded by the graphs of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, and the vertical line <math alttext=" x equals 1" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, as shown in Figure 1. Let <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi></math> be the shaded region in Quadrant IV bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis, and the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-axis, as shown in Figure 2.

(a) Find the area of <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>R</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

(b) Write, but do not evaluate, an integral expression that gives the volume of the solid generated when <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is rotated about the horizontal line <math alttext="y equals 8" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>y</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>8</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

(c) The region <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi></math> is the base of a solid. For this solid, each cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-axis is a rectangle with height <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and base in region <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi>S</mi></math>. Write, but do not evaluate, an integral expression that gives the volume of this solid.

topic.text: 8.4: Finding the Area Between Curves Expressed as Functions of x

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Identify an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test to apply.
